title: Talent Album Number One (Auditions) - FLAC 48kHz/16bit
description:
Talent Album Number One (Talent Auditions) - Various Artists

(Rare private-press LP from Detroit, Michigan.)
Produced by SPECIAL RECORDINGS, INC.
VC 879-A / VC 879-B (Matrix: VC-879-A-RE / VC-879-B)
Executive Producer: Ernie Winstanley
Date/Year: Unknown (Very likely late-60s or very early 70s)
Genre: Talk/Ads/Vocal

Vinyl Condition: (Visually) NM (Yet sound is a bit imperfect)
Dynamic Range: DR13 (Dynamic Range analysis text included)
Sample Rate: 48000 Hz
Sample Depth: 16 bit

AT-LP120-USB Direct Drive Professional Turntable (Quartz lock engaged) / AT120E/t Dual Moving Magnet Cartridge (Technics-aligned) / Adobe Audition CC v6.0 (light pop reduction, slight manual pop repair, NEVER ANY NOISE REDUCTION OR EQ!)


Tracks:

A1) Whit Vernon	
A2) Paul Caplan	
A3) Leon McNew	
A4) Jay Michael - "Do Not Play"	
A5) Rolly Parker	
A6) Jim Wood	
A7) Bud Haggart	
A8) Rube Weiss	
A9) J. P. McCarthy	
A10) Sonny Eliot	
A11) Joe Penberthy	
A12) Bob Murphy	
B1) Ernie Winstanley	
B2) George Hunter	
B3) Wally Keip	
B4) Mary Lou Zieve	
B5) Pam Guest	
B6) Eileen Conway	
B7) Gloria Beemer	
B8) Lee Murray	
B9) Marilyn Barnett	
B10) Liz Weiss	
B11) Moya Taormina	
B12) Paula McKinney


Review:
An interesting piece from what some might consider the end of the radio era. This record has a lot of fascinating recordings, as it appears to have been used to advertise individuals for radio broadcast, television commercials, or other commercial venues. Noteworthy are people like J. P. McCarthy, who would become the morning man/interviewer for Detroit's own 760 AM (WJR). I would classify this record as more of a historical fascination than quintessential collection of songs; nonetheless, the difficulty in finding a copy worthy of a pursuing collector is extremely real. Here's a rip from a very clean copy, although there appears to be quite a bit of noise inherent in the record itself. 

What about that track A4? If you look at the cover and record, it's titled "DO NOT PLAY" - incredibly strange. On the vinyl itself, it's very evident that the pressing plate was actually scratched with "X"s all through this track, so that people would understand this message. Obviously, it was important not to have this individual promoted, or something. I risked it. So it's also included here, but at the necessary noise level introduced by the original pressing. There is also a small blip in B6 that is not on the original vinyl, but I had already sold the record by the time I noticed this, so we will have to live with it for now.

Enjoy! It's unlikely you'll ever see a CD of this one ...
